job_title: Senior Cloud Applications Architect in Bogotá, Bogota
pros:
You will be working side by side with the best professionals in your region. Will learn a lot about industries, segments, computer science, languages, platforms and technologies. Customers will respect you because you're on the top cloud company, people from competence will ask how to apply to a job.

Change your role or relocate to your preferred country in AWS is 100% possible, so there are a lot of opportunities to work.
cons: Work/Life balance is hard, may be impossible to accomplish. I've traveled 60 times in a year previous to pandemic. Working right now at home, is hard. Even having your time scheduled 100% for a customer AWS ask you to spare time reviewing opportunities, doing presales jobs, hiring people, giving and receiving training. It's hard to adapt. If you're single and no plans to be married and kids you will love Amazon. For me (the opposite) eight hours by day isn't enough to be a top consultant.

review_title: Great to Start your Career, Not so Great to Stay
job_title: IT Support Engineer II in Munich, Bavaria
pros: You learn a lot while working at Amazon, especially in the IT team. There are continuous changes and always something to learn or improve on. It is a great place to start your career, and looks great on your CV.
cons: The IT job is now completely remote, you sit behind a desk all day and just answer remote chat questions. Management is only focused on cost cutting, new employees don't get hired, and you sometimes feel that you are always fighting fires. The focus is never put on how do we fix the problem, but always who do we blame first, and no one wants to be blamed first. And there will always be work, you can easily work 80 hour weeks, but no one is expecting to you to. And that can make learning new things also hard, since you won't always have time. For me, I spent most of my time learning extra curricular things outside of work, i.e. scripting/programming.

job_title: Part-Time Seasonal Fresh Associate in Wood Dale, IL
pros:
You can stay active on the job and walk several miles each shift. 

It is kind of fun at first and meditative to do a repetitive, physical task like picking groceries. However, this can get boring after a while. It is nice temporary seasonal job to have though.
cons:
There was more emphasis on maintaining picking rates (picking a certain amount of groceries per hour) instead of instruction on picking quality/unexpired foods and throwing expired foods away. Some employees would ignore sanitary concerns (wiping nose on gloves or going to bathroom with uniform) instead of taking the time to use the restroom properly, maybe because of concerns with their picking rate. And the rates were pretty hard to maintain (especially on days where not many orders were coming in).

You can possible get multiple consecutive orders in the freezer or chilled section (they might have changed this since I worked there). However, my manager was pretty cool if I told him the computer system was sending me to the freezer a lot, and he would reassign me to the warmer food section.

pros:
Frees up your enterprise, so it can focus on core competencie
Helps in leveraging economies of scale
cons:
Sometimes disrupts corporate culture. No one wants to lose his or her job due to outsourcing. In some situations, when a third party can better handle the work, it could mean the elimination of jobs within the organization.
Requires planning. BPO is not a matter of making the decision and then handing things over to a third party. It takes a lot of planning. For example, there should be a point person at the enterprise who will manage the relationship. Careful consideration should also be made when choosing the service provider, which requires a lot of planning and analysis.
Sometimes there are hidden costs. Watch for hidden costs, such as legal expenses, when moving ahead with BPO. Make sure everything is spelled out in the agreement, so there are no financial surprises.

* Uneven distribution of work at times.
* Office politics but it is largely dependent on the team you are in. There are some amazing teams with good management and there are teams with a mix of good and bad.
* Not all teams operate upto the high bar of Amazon. Imbalance between the bars maintained by different orgs.
* Good compensation but no luxurious benefits like other FAANG companies.

job_title: Software Development Engineer II in Toronto, ON
pros:
- You can learn a LOT
- You can work on huge projects with lots of users and lots of data (terabytes, petabytes...)
- You can use AWS almost limitless. Other companies usually worry about costs. Here I'm working on a team with an annual AWS cost around ~$1M... You can experiment a lot with that kind of budget
- No overtime, no problem taking days off and PTO
cons:
- large turnover in the teams, after 1.5 years I am the only one left from the team that I joined of 7 developers
- the leadership principle called "Frugality": it affects employees as well... don't expect huge raises and bonuses unless you are willing to work 150%
- internal frameworks, tools: we use lots of internally developed tools and frameworks, you will have to learn a LOT, and you won't be able to use that at other companies

pros: Driving job, can make ok money.
cons:
Too many packages. Amazon will tell you safety and customers is their priority and not how many parcels you deliver. The reality is very different.
There is a public face of Amazon, and then there is the reality of a greedy company that puts too much pressure on the “Delivery Service Partners”, who in turn pile that pressure onto their self employed drivers. If you don’t mind cutting corners like not putting a seatbelt on and just parking anywhere, blocking roads & driveways, you’ll get on fine. If you like to do things right, be safe and treat other road users with respect, this is not the job for you!
Also they say it’s a 9 hour shift, but that doesn’t include the hour you sit in an overflow car park, or loading time. Also you have to install an app that monitors every aspect of your driving. If you go over the speed limit at all, have to brake, accelerate or go round corners to harshly, you get a poor score and therefore not eligible for bonuses.
Be wary of the money promised in job adverts. Most are based on bonuses, and many hidden costs like £50 for background checks, £12 a week for your payslip. If you hire one of the companies vans and it gets damaged, don’t tell them, get it fixed yourself, they’ll rip you off for repairs.
Shame, could be a good job and the other drivers in your team are usually pretty decent, but the hypocrisy, double standards and BS will drive you mad!

job_title: Software Development Engineer (SDE) II in Vancouver, BC
pros:
* Stocks going up which is good. Lots of potential to continue growing.
* Lots of smart and experienced people to learn from.
* Get to work with very large scale distributed systems that handle million TPS.
* Overtime, learned the skill to work fast and efficiently due to pressure and priorities.
* If picking a team that's internal facing (like People/Accounting tech) or brand new team, life would be easier.
cons:
* Avoid teams that has heavy operational load, such as oncall. Constantly getting paged is stressful.
* Avoid small teams.
* Avoid teams that don't have a lot of business driven projects, because you won't get to code as much, which is essential to push your SDE promotion forward.
* Always have a sense of feeling that teams over-commit to things which puts pressure on teams to work faster/deliver more.
* Not often, but once in a while, seeing peers getting piped, particular in teams based in Seattle.

review_title: Get in and then get out ASAP
pros: Amazon is like school. You'll learn a lot and will be better off for it if you can get out unscathed. It can be exhilarating at times getting to work on such a large scale and at such a fast pace. There's a lot of career opportunities as well. You have the means to switch careers, switch industries, or move abroad. It's great for your resume. You'll likely take the lessons you learn here with you through the rest of your career.
cons: Amazon's ways of working, whether intentional or not, is brutal and can feel like the movie "Whiplash" at times. I have a hard time recommending this place to people experiencing mental illness, the chronically ill, the neurodivergent, or people with families. This place will wear you down. Work/life balance is extremely poor. Compensation falls off a cliff after the first 4 years, and it doesn't make much financial sense to stay longer that. You could make more money and have better benefits at tech companies of a similar stature and be way less miserable.

review_title: "A challenging job in a very fast paced environment"
pros: You get to work for one of the greatest companies in the world, which for those who can read through the lines, means plenty of opportunities if you know how to navigate those waters.
cons: Amazon Logistics unfortunately can get repetitive and if not equipped with the right mindset can become demotivating. The shifts are too long, especially working night shifts. Salary could be improved considering the work required.

pros:
-Schedule flexibility
-They hire fast, but there is a downside to this. They don't support labor unions, so I've been fired without any reasoning at all. There's no Amazon HR that will take your calls, and no way to fight discrimination. They don't even have any paperwork that you need to sign, you're just terminated. This almost caused to be homeless after I got fired with no warning.

-Decent health insurance
cons:
-Pay. There are no raises. $15/hr is where you stay. You may get promoted to Driver Lead which makes $17/hr. Always remember there's no actual promotional chances...

-401k/Savings. There's no real retirement plan. Their 401k plan is horrible at 3% matching, on a $15/hr paycheck. You may have $5,000 if you did this for 15 years in your 401k account...The other companies do significantly better with this.

- Hours. Some routes are insane. They don't adjust for weather conditions, rain, 110 degree heat, and I've been forced to deliver in the middle of a flash flood warning. I've had routes that take 11-12 hours (The most you can work).

-Overworked. A lot of people don't understand operation costs. FedEx pays more, and UPS pays way more. You just delivered 275 packages, and probably about $10,000-$15,000 worth of items. They can pay you way more than working your entire butt off for $150. There are times when you don't have time to go to the bathroom (sometimes a 10-15 minute drive), you're working and it's pitch black outside, it's freezing cold or blazing hot, and there's not enough time to reasonably take lunch breaks. Running from house to house, driving 1000 miles/hr in a giant van while you're staring at a gps and about to run over a small child. You can forget that you're working for the richest person in the world, honestly. 

-Poor life balance. Long hours, low pay, means you have to pick up extra days. Not bad if you only need a part time gig.
-If they eventually get a labor union, Amazon would be flooded with complaints, and the entire company would need a remodel. 

Other companies pay more for this position, but most people think Amazon is the best. Reconsider FedEx at $18/hr with raises and UPS is like $22/hr with raises each year.

pros: Flex is perhaps the best benefit for working for amazon. Being able to pick up as little or as many shifts as you want throughout the week is great for people that have multiple jobs and want an extra side hustle.
cons: Trying to work the job as a full-time job is taxing on the body. Constantly being criticized over pace and rates. Not much time spent on training since management only cares about numbers. You are just a cog in the machine, you have no value. You literally are a warm body that is very easily replaced. This is evident by how many people Amazon hires at any given time. Those are new hires are to fill spots that people have quit from.

pros:
* Good pay
* Easy to move between teams
* You can find any project/technology under the sun
* Unlimited opportunities to make an impact and learn
* Good work/life balance (depending on the team)
cons:
* The bar for SDEs has slipped so low, e.g. hiring engineers who barely know how binary search works; actually the bar for all roles has slipped, you will encounter a lot of people with questionable intelligence in your day to day
* The squeaky wheel gets the grease: only those who complain/brownnose get promoted, not the people who actually should be promoted
* Resource-strapped, you will be expected to do 3 other jobs in addition to yours (especially in AWS, avoid it like the plague) and somehow deliver precisely on time on ETAs
* All of the good managers left a long time ago
* Leadership principles once meant something and I'll admit I kind of liked them, but now they only apply to lowly SDEs (never to managers) and are only thrown in when convenient to justify someone's POV
* The compensation review process is completely opaque and they are getting stingier every year without much justification
* On call can be brutal
* Each team at Amazon is like its own kingdom, meaning that getting cooperation to integrate code or align on deliverables is almost always a battle
* Super hierarchical, everything (dates, requirements, policies, what you will work on, etc.) are handed down from on high with little ability for engineers to give input and extreme emphasis is placed on a person's level: "a lowly level 5 questioning a level 6??  Impossible!"
* Diversity means nothing and is only paid lip service; in my more than a half a decade career at Amazon, I was always the only person of my ethnicity on my floor... and I worked in several buildings during my tenure

pros: They give their employees a free pair of shoes once per year. They allow their employees to drink free cheap powder instant coffee.
cons: Their hours are grueling and their management style is unprofessional. What really bothers me about this company is that I elected for employee stock options in my benefit enrollment and have been chasing representatives via email just to get ahold of MY stocks (which I absolutely would like to sell). The richest man in the world at the time couldn’t even afford to feed his employees. Let that sink in. A billionaire atop of a trillion dollar company profits from selling its hungry employees potato chips and egg salad while investing millions into their hardware and warehouse facilities and vehicles and more. I had plenty of reservations going into this employment opportunity and every single one of them was confirmed. They could be offering 5 dollars above the industry average and I’d still advise jobseekers to look elsewhere. It wouldn’t surprise me if this company goes belly up In 10 years or less when people recognize the shoddy quality of service they provide. Not sure if I could be any less satisfied from an employment experience. Job interview was literally just swabbing my mouth to see if I was on drugs. Never once had the pleasure of being introduced to the warehouse manager and my job functions we’re not clearly explained upon interview, employment offer or any other part of the process. Would rate negative stars if it were possible. This company is without a doubt the worst company I’ve ever had the displeasure of donating my time to. No wonder the divorced dork who disenfranchised millions of college kids building his text book “scampire” has done such a masterful job of constructing a dystopian Hell.

review_title: Grow your Career, Leadership skills by trading for WLB
job_title: Senior Program Manager in Seattle, WA
pros: Amazing opportunity to drive huge programs across multiple teams. Success is determined by you and the availability of other teams, Writing and communication skills go far, and technical ability multiplies your success with dividends. At Amazon you can become a subject matter expert in an area of business in just several weeks, drive improvements and get recognition quickly. Amazon allows almost unlimited creativity for those that like to think big and then drive to completion. Amazon will teach you how to earn the trust of others and become a leader by necessity and practice. Experience gained and networking acquired across multiple teams and organizations is determined by your own cadence however these open up unlimited and massive opportunities in the company YoY.
cons: Very hard to maintain work life balance. You will generally work a level up while getting payed a level down at amazon. Getting promoted is largely determined by continuously proving your case that you are succeeding at current level, writing your own promo docs (even though your boss is supposed to to that). Burnout is real and will happen faster than other companies. Working for amazon is alot like PBR, just have to hold on for 8 seconds and you can win the rodeo but you can also end up with damaged social life/WLB/relationships outside of work. It maybe worth it, but you have to be consciously assessing mental health and checking for burnout. Many people roll into December with full vacation/PTO becuase there is never a good time to take off. Growing a career at amazon maybe a good flavor of life to choose for someone as it provides opportunity for all as long as you deliver results. Overall I would recommend for someone looking to grow and promote fast at a tech company but those that value life outside work should look elsewhere. Amazon is getting big and slow, if you have the ability to drive with agility and flexibility you will be more successful than your peers and get more results. At Amazon you need to get used to driving programs with little to no support, and doing the job of 3-4 people. Amazon mentorship program exists but it is weak, Mentorship program at amazon could become a huge strength for the company if it had more support behind it. The constant turnover of business/tech/operation teams is almost unbelievable, and is slowing many large scale programs and initiatives. Amazon needs to solve the continuous attrition of good workers getting burned out/under-payed/over worked, or at least slow it to a reasonable level. Right now the attrition at the company makes it difficult for teams to move forward when all employees for a given team turn over in 6-12 months, leaving few to no SME for respective fields. Amazon needs to cultivate talent and turn those new hires and transfers into the next generation of leaders and executives rather than continue suffering the same fate year after year as the talent base runs away.
